tr.td: This goal lists all the applications installed on a WebSphere Server or Cell.
This task enables you to start an existing or newly installed application on a WebSphere Server or in a WebSphere Cell.
This goal generates WebSphere specific deploymentcode for an ejb jarfile.
The WSDL2Java task creates Java classes and deployment descriptor templates from a Web Services Description Language (WSDL) file.
This task enables you to stop an existing application on a WebSphere Server or in a WebSphere Cell.
The ServerStatus task enables you to get status on a server instance or all server instances.
Installs an ear/war/jar file to WebSphere.

This task enables you to stop a standalone server instance. This is not used to stop a server controlled by DeploymentManager. Therefore, this task is useful for the Base Application Server, and to stop the Node Agent and/or DeploymentManager.

This task enables you to start a standalone server instance. This is not used to start a server controlled by DeploymentManager. Therefore, this task is useful for the Base Application Server, and to start the Node Agent and/or DeploymentManager. If you wish to start a server managed by the Deployment Manager, use the wsadmin task to execute a scripting command

The Java2WSDL command maps a Java class to a Web Services Description Language (WSDL) file by following the Java API for XML-based remote procedure call (JAX-RPC) specification. The Java2WSDL command accepts a Java class as input and produces a WSDL file representing the input class. If there is an existing file at the output location, it is overwritten. The WSDL file generated by the Java2WSDL command contains WSDL and XML schema constructs that are automatically derived from the input class. You can override these default values with command-line arguments.
